Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Integrated Dynamic Spectrum Access for Throughput, Delay, and Fairness Enhancement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central theme of this project is to investigate methodologies and theories to enhance throughput, delay, and fairness of cognitive radio networks via integrated dynamic spectrum access. The research will develop new methods to:
1) Extend spectrum sensing beyond just the presence and absence of the primary spectrum users' activities at certain spectrum bands/channels, but also their locations and transmit powers
2) Predict the primary spectrum user's activity and its interval using game theoretic and statistical learning approaches
3) Perform delay-aware spectrum management with a very comprehensive delay model considering all the factors that may affect the delivery latency of a packet, including the spectrum sensing delay, the transmission delay, the queuing delay, and the spectrum negotiation and scheduling delay
4) Share spectrum in a fair manner considering the tradeoff between fairness and throughput
5) Propose a delay-aware fair routing protocol for throughput optimization which jointly considers throughput, delay, and fairness along with dynamic spectrum management.

The project's focus on dynamic spectrum access is of high national interest and can create significant impact on spectral usage policies and related industries in the telecommunication and information technology sectors. The project will also encourage and include under-represented and minority students to be part of this activity, while extending education and outreach plans to undergraduates and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the exponential increase in the number of mobile devices and services, demand for spectrum is bound to outpace availability, under current spectrum management policies. This is due to the fact that, under static allocation of spectrum througfIh auctions, large swaths of spectrum remain underutilized, resulting in a severe spectrum scarcity problem. The implication that spectrum may not be scarce in the traditional sense calls for a paradigm shift in the way spectrum is allocated. Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA), enabled by Cognitive Radio (CR) technology, has emerged as solution to the spectrum scarcity problem. The central theme of this project is to investigate novel theories and system approaches to enhance throughput, delay, and fairness in wireless cognitive radio networks. Several fundamentals issues are investigated under this project, including spectrum sensing, spectrum prediction, delay-aware spectrum management, and fair spectrum sharing.

The main objective of the project is the development of integrated techniques, protocols and mechanisms to enable dynamic and opportunistic use of and access to the available radio spectrum resources. Interdisciplinary methodology, involving Bayesian theory, statistical learning and game theory, have been also used to develop efficient approaches to predict PU status and spectrum availability, to design multi-channel proportionally-fair media access control schemes and delay-aware routing protocols, and to develop new techniques for mitigating the impact of jamming signals originated from malicious users.

As part of this research project, we developed cooperative spectrum prediction approaches for cognitive radio networks supporting multi-primary and multi-secondary users. The cooperative group formation process is modeled as a coalitional game and a coalition formation algorithm was developed. The results show that higher prediction accuracy can be achieved when secondary users cooperate in making spectrum usage. We have also investigated new approaches for spectrum sensing by exploring the tradeoffs between energy consumption and secondary network throughput. The results show that careful tuning of key parameters leads to improved energy efficiency and increased secondary network throughput. We developed a framework for cooperative relaying and derived feasible relay location region and optimal power ratio between the primary Annetwork and the secondary network. These results were used to derive the maximum achievable transmission capacity of the secondary network under the outage constraints from both the primary and the secondary network with or without cooperative relaying. We also studied cooperative techniques that rely on femtocell user diversity to improve the downlink communication quality of macrocell users. The simulation results shows that, under reasonable SNR values, cooperative schemes significantly enhance the performances of macrocells by improving bit-error-rate, outage probability, and data throughput of macrocell users.

Another focus of this reearch period was on developing privacy-preserving access to geo-location databased to support channle availability queries in cognitive radio networks. The use of a geo-location database (gDB) shifts the burden of obtaining spectrum availability from the resource-constrained user’s device to the database. The use of such a database, however, may lead to the violation of a secondary user’s privacy. In particular, the database administrator may use information contained in the spectrum availability query to infer the actual geo-location of a secondary user (SU). This information can be used for different purposes, including disclosure of confidential matters, financial gains, blackmailing and other harmful endeavors. Several approaches have been proposed to preserve location privacy in database-enabled cognitive radio networks. Some of these approaches avoid sharing complete information of the user’s location, while others only share information of the user’s geo-location with the gDB. Typically, these approaches end up requesting more information than needed to determine channel availability in a specific location. In this work, we take a different approach to address SUs’ location privacy in database-enabled cognitive wireless networks. The basic tenet of the proposed privacy-preserving dDB access framework is obfuscation, whereby channel requests for valid locations are interwoven with requests for fake locations. Traffic redirection is also used to deliberately confuse potential query monitors from inferring users’ location information. Within this framework, we propose two privacy-preserving schemes. The Master Device Enabled Location Privacy Preserving (MD-Enabled LPP) scheme relies on trusted master devices to secure relay SU queries and prevent leaking information of SUs’ locations to attackers. The Crowd Sourced Location Privacy Preserving (CSLPP) scheme builds a guided tour of randomly selected volunteers to deliver users channel availability queries and ensure location privacy. 

The research ﬁndings, publically accessible through the project website, have been published in high-quality journals, and were presented in major venues in the areas of wireless and cognitive networks. At the education level, the project involved students from under-represented groups, presenting them with a unique opportunity to gain invaluable experience in the field of wireless cognitive networks.
